snippet: More than a decade ago, tele-ICU command centers were trumpeted as the new standard in critical care, but the growth of such systems has stalled.
abstract: Independent studies question the effectiveness and cost-efficiency of tele-ICU command centers, once touted as new standard in critical care; growth in the systems, which allow doctors to monitor intensive care patients remotely, has stalled in recent years; many hospitals in the New York area and nationwide that adopted the technology have since discontinued its use.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, tele-ICU command centers were trumpeted as the new standard in critical care, but the growth of such systems has stalled.

headline.seo: Promise of Centers for Remote Monitoring of ICU Patients Is Called Into Question
headline.main: The Doctor Is In, but Hundreds of Miles Away
headline.print_headline: Debating the Effectiveness of Remotely Monitoring Intensive Care Patients
